                                A Practice-Oriented Education for Global Public Service   NYU Wagner offers an interdisciplinary professional education for practice-oriented global public service. U.S. and international students alike are drawn to the school's unique and diverse international course offerings, which bridge various degree programs. Wagner graduates go on to serve in a variety of international public service careers in the U.S. and abroad.       MPA and MUP: International Specializations   Students can pursue an International specialization within Wagner's Master of Public Administration and Master of Urban Planning programs:   MPA: Public and Nonprofit Management and Policy (PNP)   MPA: Health Policy and Management (HPAM)   Master of Urban Planning (MUP)   By blending theory and practice, NYU Wagner equips students with knowledge and analytical skills designed to help them tackle conceptual issues, as well as the implementation challenges and real world constraints typically faced by global public service practitioners.       Executive MPA of International Public Service Organizations   An Executive MPA of International Public Service Organizations  is also available to experienced professionals who aspire to widen their background in management to achieve positions of greater leadership responsibility. A 36-credit program, the Executive MPA Program combines workshops, courses and seminars to provide students with a theoretical and practical understanding of international management. Film from the International Perspective: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Graduate Film Admissions About our Programs  News & Events Showcase Faculty Facilities MBA/MFA Dual Degree The Purple List Facebook TSOA FTV Wiki First Run Festival Cinema Research Institute  home > Graduate Film        Film from the International Perspective  GFMTV-GT.2284 Lecture 2 Credits The geography of the film world is rapidly changing. It no longer revolves exclusively around Hollywood, or even the U.S. There are growing and thriving Film Industries throughout the International map, with foreign directors, writers, and actors becoming artistically and commercially successful on a world wide basis. Films indigenous to their own nations are gaining an increasingly large share of their local box office pies, and opportunities abound around the world for new filmmakers to gain entry and thrive in foreign lands. Many US films are earning a disproportionate share of their total revenues overseas. Foreign financing is evolving into an essential component of funds available to make films anywhere in the world; including the U.S. For a film student hoping to get their films made an understanding of how industry works on a worldwide basis; is a key element in having a successful film career. The course will examine the historical changes that have occurred in the foreign markets and attempt to forecast where the business is headed internationally. Most importantly the course is designed to create an awareness in graduate film students as how to access jobs in foreign countries. the World   As part of a global network university , Wagner promotes the importance of taking a global approach to studying the complex issues in public service. Via the curriculum, workshops, professional experiences and events, the school provides students with many opportunities to enhance their global knowledge and develop cross-cultural competency. The Global Executive MPA program is offered jointly with University College London's School of Public Policy (UCL). Students spend one semester at Wagner, one at UCL, and one semester at locations across the globe.                                 A Practice-Oriented Education for Global Public Service   NYU Wagner offers an interdisciplinary professional education for practice-oriented global public service. U.S. and international students alike are drawn to the school's unique and diverse international course offerings, which bridge various degree programs. Wagner graduates go on to serve in a variety of international public service careers in the U.S. and abroad.       MPA and MUP: International Specializations   Students can pursue an International specialization within Wagner's Master of Public Administration and Master of Urban Planning programs:   MPA: Public and Nonprofit Management and Policy (PNP)   MPA: Health Policy and Management (HPAM)   Master of Urban Planning (MUP)   By blending theory and practice, NYU Wagner equips students with knowledge and analytical skills designed to help them tackle conceptual issues, as well as the implementation challenges and real world constraints typically faced by global public service practitioners.       Executive MPA of International Public Service Organizations   An Executive MPA of International Public Service Organizations  is also available to experienced professionals who aspire to widen their background in management to achieve positions of greater leadership responsibility. A 36-credit program, the Executive MPA Program combines workshops, courses and seminars to provide students with a theoretical and practical understanding of international management. Film from the International Perspective: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Graduate Film Admissions About our Programs  News & Events Showcase Faculty Facilities MBA/MFA Dual Degree The Purple List Facebook TSOA FTV Wiki First Run Festival Cinema Research Institute  home > Graduate Film        Film from the International Perspective  GFMTV-GT.2284 Lecture 2 Credits The geography of the film world is rapidly changing. It no longer revolves exclusively around Hollywood, or even the U.S. There are growing and thriving Film Industries throughout the International map, with foreign directors, writers, and actors becoming artistically and commercially successful on a world wide basis. Films indigenous to their own nations are gaining an increasingly large share of their local box office pies, and opportunities abound around the world for new filmmakers to gain entry and thrive in foreign lands. Many US films are earning a disproportionate share of their total revenues overseas. Foreign financing is evolving into an essential component of funds available to make films anywhere in the world; including the U.S. For a film student hoping to get their films made an understanding of how industry works on a worldwide basis; is a key element in having a successful film career. The course will examine the historical changes that have occurred in the foreign markets and attempt to forecast where the business is headed internationally. Most importantly the course is designed to create an awareness in graduate film students as how to access jobs in foreign countries.
